newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Chronology of Ecuador's political crisis.
newsitem.headline: Chronology of Ecuador's political crisis.

text.p: The following is a brief chronology of events in Ecuador's political crisis that led to the ouster of democratically elected President Abdala Bucaram.
Jan. 8 - The administration of President Abdala Bucaram launches austerity package, including stiff increases in electricity, gas and public transport.
Feb. 5 - First day of a 48-hour general strike to protest the government's austerity measures. Protesters calling for Bucaram's resignation clash with police near presidential palace.
Feb. 6 - Trade unions extend walkout indefinitely or until Bucaram is dismissed.
- Army troops clash with demonstrators outside the presidential place.

- Congress votes by 44-34 to oust Bucaram on grounds of mental incompetence, then swears in its leader Fabian Alarcon. Bucaram rejects the vote as "judicial barbarity," suggesting bid to depose him was engineered by economic elite.
Feb. 7 - Vice President Rosalia Arteaga declares her own right to the presidency as Ecuador wakes up with three "presidents."
- Defence minister declares state of emergency, which suspends the right to stage public demonstrations and other individual guarantees.
- One person killed, scores injured in disturbances outside presidential palace as up to 4,000 protesters move to take the palace by force.
- Bucaram leaves presidential palace to spend four-day carnival weekend in his home in the Pacific coast city of Guayaquil.
Feb. 8 - Defence Minister Gen. Victor Bayas announces his resignation.
- Bucaram says he would rather die than step down in disgrace.
- Leading regional army chief Gen. Jose Grijalva says the military is not taking orders from Bucaram "since he is no longer in charge and was destituted by Congress."

Feb. 9 - Legislators and military leaders agree on a plan allowing Vice President Arteaga to take over as interim president for a few days until Congress passes new legislation to reappoint Alarcon as president until August 1998, following elections in May or June.
- Bucaram concedes defeat, saying he was deposed in a military-backed "congressional coup" but vows to make a political comeback.
